row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

cell.p: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.

This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: THE UNREST IN THE FAR EAST.
div.p: Mr. Angus Hamilton has some interesting speculations as to what will happen in the Par East when China and Japan really find themselves, the article appearing in the third part of the "Harmsworth History of the World".

"Looking back at the conditions of Asia in the eighteenth shd nineteenth centuries, and comparing them with those existing today, it will be noticed that a wide a gulf separates Japan from China in the twentieth century As then separated China from the rest of the Par East. On one side there is Chins, anemotiofál, and only slightly irraptive; on the other there is Japan, voicing the regeneration of Asia with raucous tones.....

"While China is commercially independent of the West, and Japan dependent apon it, all branches of foreign industry cannot but view with alarm the increasing aggressiveness of the spirit of independence now inspiring Asia at the prompting of Japan. Obviously these signs are the indication of an approaching cleavage between East and West, which, when tally attained, will bear witness to the complete severance of the shackles bitherto enthralling Asia to the interests and purposes of the West.

"It must not be forgotten that Japan already has achieved her complete regeneration Thirty years hence China, no doubt, will have followed suit, when federacy of the Far Eastern Powers may become an accomplished fact. Byen it this moment such a union is possible, and its realisation would impose upon all European Governments the immediate revision of their Asiatic policies.

"At this time such a combination is hampered only by the unwillingness of China to accept the suggestions of Japan in anything affecting the policy of Asia, although, in spite of this objection, active reforming influences are gre deally effecting important changes throughout the Chinese Empire. For the momennt, therefore, Japan is content to tread alone the path she has marked out, encouraging her subjects by example to exploit Asia for the Asiatios, and to secure recognition of the doctrine of equality between the white and Asiatic moes.

"If the full significance of this movement is not yet discernible, there is enough evider to show that the problem will rank among the greatest that the polities of the twentieth cen tary can disclose. Not only one part of the civilised globe will be affected by the rise of dominant Asia, for the whole world will be confronted equally with the necessity of resist ing whatever indications may appear, If it is difficult to devise an arrangement short of total exclusion that does not admit an annual influx of a large number of Japanese, Chinese, Korean, or Indian immigrants into the lands affected by this invasion, it is at least tolerably certain that if the existing flow of Asiaties across the Pacific to America and Australasia continues unabated for further decade, the areas now menaced will be inhabited by a white minority.

"It appears evident that the continuation of the Far East under existing conditions is doubtful, if not impossible, in view of the awakening of Asia and the visible prejudices that Western democracy entertains against the Asiatio. Yet if the clash of conflicting interests ultimately precipitātes a struggle between the two great racial divisions of the world, there can be no doubt that the moral teachings of humanity will be discredited."

div.p: The Postal Administration has just issued a new 3 millièmes stamped envelope.

div.head: Egyptian Ivory
div.p: 12 1/2 tons Egyptian Ivory have arrived in London for the quarterly sales January 28th.

div.head: The Cairo Punch.
div.p: Such is the title of a new comic weekly paper, which is to appear on the 15th proses. The editor and proprietor is Mr. A.H. Zaki.

div.head: St. Andrews Dinner
div.p: At least seventy Scotsmen are expected to attend the dinner on St. Andrew's Day at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo. Haggis will, as usual, be one of the chief items of the bill of fare,

div.head: Standard Life Assurance Co.
div.p: In consequence of the sale of the Company's building, the offices of the Standard Life Assurance Company will be removed to the new building of the Egyptian Estates, Limited on 1st December next.

div.head: Khedivial Geographical Society
div.p: A meeting of the Khedivial Geographical Soeiety will be held in the hall of the Legislative Council at 3-30 p.m. to-morrow, when a paper on "From Cairo to Damascus" will be read by Abbate Pasha

div.head: Tanzim Department
div.p: A correspondent writes from Cairo that it is rumoured that the Tanzim Department of the Government is to be handed over to the Mudirs Governors either at the end of the financial or the Calendar year.

div.head: Bubonic Plague
div.p: Two patients who have been under treatment for plague have been discharged cured at Alexandria, one death has occurred at Simbelaneni, and one fresh case has come in for treatment at Ago, this bringing the total at present under treatment to sixteen.

div.head: Feneh Barrage
div.p: From the 15th inst. markabs bave been placed in the middle of the river at Esneh with the navigation channel in the middle owing to sadd being constructed from the East bank of the river westward. During the night the markabs will burn red lights.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe via Port-Said and Brindisi will be made up at the G.P.O. Alexandria, at 2 40 p.m. on Sunday 24th for ordinary correspondence, 1.40 p.m. for registered correspondence, at noon for money orders and insured articles and at 6 pm. on Saturday 23rd for parcels.

div.head: Zizinia Theatre
div.p: There was a fair attendance last night at the Zizinia Theatre when "La Passerelle" was given. Madame Munte took the part of Jaqueline, which she impersonated to perfection. This very Parisian play is eminently suited to the palates of the Alexandrian play. goers and the comedy was followed with much gusto and roars of laughter attended her acting. She was well seconded by her troupe.

div.head: First Circle Canals.
div.p: In consequence of the annual cleaning of the canals in the 1st Circle of Irrigation, the water in all such will be reduced to too low a level to admit of navigation for a period of thirty days rom the 10th December prox, the Canal Ismailia will however not be closed antil the 15th prox when for thirty days it will only contain water sufficient for the navigation of the smallest boats.

div.head: The Language of the Country
div.p: A certain number of persons newly arrived will be glad to know that the Berlitz School andertakes to teach the Arabic language on he same method and principles as are applied to the study of English, French and all the other modern languages. The results are most remarkable and those who have any doubts on the subject need only take a lesson to be con inced of this fact. (Advt.)

div.head: Chief Merchant of Khartoum.
div.p: At the merchants' meeting held at the Omdurman Zaptieh on Monday week Slatin Pasha announced the dismissal of Mohammed Bey Hassan from his appointment as Chief Merchant of Khartoum, by order of the Governor General. The reasons for the dismissal as brought out in the order, are the incompetency of Mohamed Bey and his unfitness for the position - his private affairs even being in lack of proper management, -and the hostility he has manifested to certain officers holding Government offices, against whom he brought certain charges which he could not substantiate, and which upon enquiry proved to be entirely without foundation. The office of Chief Merchant was declared vacant and the bope was expressed that the Government, would be led co choose a suitable person for the place.

div.head:
LORD CROMER ON FREE TRADE
ARGUMENTS AGAINST PROTECTION.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)

LONDON, Friday. Lord Cromer, who was the guest of honour at the Unionist Free Trade dinner last night, said that he had been all his life a strong imperialist and free trader. If once we change free trade we shall quicken into life every form of dormant Anglophobia which exists throughout the world, every jealousy entertained by Chauvinists abroad will be transferred to the counting house of every foreign manfacturing merchant. When once the passion which protection or even preference will evoke has been let loose, our present naval establishments, great though they be, will be insuficient. I wish Unionista could agree to differ and let tariff reform sleep.

div.head: THE LATE JUDGE HILLS
div.p: The late Judge Hills of Highhead Castle, Cumberland, the news of whose death early on the morning of Monday, November 11th, will have been received with keen regret by a large circle of friends and acquaintances, was born in 1837. He was the son of John Hills of Walmer, Kent, and spent his childhood in Italy; from which circumstance he acquired that intimate knowledge of the Italian language which he never lost, and which was of such value to him in after life. At the age of 18 he went to Eton, afterwards going to Balliol College, Oxford, where he graduated as B.A. in 1860. Upon leaving the University he entered the profession of law, and was called to the bar in 1864.

For five years be filled the post of secretary to the Lord Privy Seal, (the late Duke of Argyll) for which he was specially recommended by Dr. Jowett, late Master of Balliol, on resigning this appointment he practised as a barrister in London, and on the northern circuit till 1875. In 1863 he married a daughter of the late Rt. Hon. Sir William Grove, P.C. F.R.S. the distinguished scientist and Judge of the High Court.

In the summer of 1875 Mr. Hills was offered by Lord Derby, the then Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, the post of Judge in the newly constituted International Tribunals in Egypt. This offer he accepted. In these Courts Great Britain had the right of nominating two members of the judicial bench. Mr. Hills' companion in this honour was Mr. John Scott (afterwards Sir John Scott, Judicial Adviser to the Khedive.) In 1882 he was promoted to the Court of Appeal in Alexandria, and retained his seat upon the bench of that tribunal, a position which he occupied with unfailing dignity and distinction, until his retirement four years ago.

In recognition of his long and valuable services he was invested by the Khedive with the order of the Medjidieh, Judge Hills was a J.P. for Cumberland, and well known in the county. For many years he rented Corby Castle, the beautiful seat of the Howards of Corby upon the Eden: and upon the completion of his official career he purchased from Lord Brougham the fine old place, Highead Castle in Cumberland, which had been allowed to fall into a derelict condition. This residence he restored with great taste and judgment, and occupied it until his death. He is survived by his wife, and his three sons; Major E. H. Hills, C.M.G., Royal Engineers, Mr. John Hills, M.P., Durham City, and Mr. Eustace Hills, Barrister-at-Law.

div.head: THE LATE CAPT. ROBERTS.
div.p: The late Captain C.P. Roberts whose untimely death occurred this week, joined the Egyptian Army on the 9th July 1901, and served for some time as inspector in the Kor Hotan district prior to his appointment to the Egyptian Artillery. Born in 1873 Captain Roberts was gazetted as second Lieutenant in the Royal Artillery in April 1893, being promoted to the rank of Lieutenant in April 1896 and obtaining his Captaincy in March 1900,

His early foreign service was divided between Gibraltar and India, at the former of which places he had served in the Field Garrrison, and at the latter in the Mountain Battery, while after his arrival in Egypt he served in the operations at Jabel Jerok for which he received the Egyptian medal with clasp. His Highness the Khedive at the same time conferred upon him the order of the Medjidieh 4th class.

div.head: CALLS AND COMPANIES.
div.p: A correspondent writes :

A large number, if not the majority of the companies floated during last season, are much hampered by the refusal of the shareholders to pay their calls. I know many persons, who have refused, because they are quite unaware as to the exact position of the companies. Nobody knows what the directors are doing And as nothing is ever published as to what these companies have done or are doing, there is naturally a disinclination to probably throw good money after bad if the company is on the brink of voluntary liquidation or, bankruptcy. Shareholders will not pay up in many cases unless the directors issue a temporary balance sheet certified by auditors, giving full details of how the company stands. Such an honest line of policy would lead to many persons paying up all the calls due.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN POLITICS
A LONDON ORGAN
div.p: After a protreted ineabation the new English monthly "Egypt", has at last seen the light

The new venture turns out, as we surmised it would, to partake of the Kamel-cum Blunt shade of opinion. A perusal of the editorial artiele makes this perfectly plain. The style is not particularly edifying; there is too much much of the cit and thrust method about it, reminding one of thosedendly obcounters, which only take place on the transpoutine stage However, we are not surprised that some writers in England, who are totally irratze of the prevailing conditions here, should do pouse the cause of Kamel, seeing that he is the one man in Egypt who has proved himself apable of conducting a campaign. But this beating of the big drum must neem, to those who know, fulsome nonsense since the chances of evacuation are, by reason of recent allianons more remote than they were ever before.

The contents of the new journal intelede the following. The Dawn of Freedom. An Open better to the British Parliament by Buhedley Norton FR SL The Education Question by a member of the Egyptian Board of Education. The Rt Hon. John Morley on the Egyptime Question. The Phantom of Egyptian Uutest by a British Stateeman ete.
PARTY OF THE PEOPLE.
TO THE EDITOR OP THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, I read in your last issue, what you have thought to be the goal of the "Party of the People" i.e. "independence." But it was "oomplete autonomy" and pot "independence that was mentioned in the virouler of the "Party of the People". It is the present autonomy as authorized by Firms and International Treaties with a little more, and that little is Chat the nation should have the right of co
perating with the government in public matters. This is what is understood from Hassan Pasha Abd al-Razik's declarations which showed the aspirations of the Party and he means for their reslization.
Your obedient servant
AHMED LOUTY EL SAD.
Director of "Al Guridah"
A DANGEROUS HISTORIAN
To the EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN CA ."

Sir, -Under the above heading you recent ay published a letter signed "Veritas" in which he "Secret History of Egypt, ato" by Mr. W.8. Blunt is somewhat severely criticised. Your correspondent omitted to mention & rather im mortant fact in connection with the appearance of this book. It is now several years since Arabi returned from exile to live in this country, and ret not one Egyptian out of a thousand knows or cares anything about him, and still leds about those whose tool he was in 1882. On hem all has fallen what the Prench pathetical y call "la pâle fleur de l'oubli." But this did mot at all suit Mr. Blunt's morbid craving for notoriety - "hine illae lachrymie" --but for bis, his "Secret History" would probably never have been written. However it will not long me remembered, and in a few years, sotons and cene shifters alike, including Mr. Blant, will have passed away, as your correspondent righty suggests, "unwept, unhonoured and unsung.
I remain, Sir,

The religious service was nonducted by a representative of the Orthodox Patriarch who was assisted by several of the rlergy of the Greek Church, and Mr. Paleologun Georgiou, headmaster of the Greek Schools of Alexandris: read the official document describing the circumstances, which was then placed in the stone with several pieces of money and copies of the "Egyptian Gazette" and the "Phare d'Alexandria." The document was signed by Mr. Sootidis, Consul General of Greece, Mr. Michel Binadino, seting President and Vice President of the Hellenic Community of Alexandria, Mr. Prazzicas, Mr. and Mr Cenophon Jowndidiss and by Mr. John Siricha, architect. The stone was laid by Mrs-Zenophow Toannidis, who broke over it a bottle of charts paign, christening it St. Michael. Immediately afterwarde Mr. Bootidis made an eloquent speech, in which he expressed the hearty thanks of the commentty w Mr. and Mrs Jonny for their generosity in providing the necessary unds for the church and to Mr. Pradinions for mis foundation of the Ibrahimjeh sehool. Mr. Seorgiou then replied with an eloquent speech refering to the patriotism, solidarity, and generosity of the Greek commitnity in Egypt which does so much for the cause of religion and education. The company then went to the Praizikio school for ita inauguration. A very pleasant afternoon we spent and the health of Messrs. div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries and Boutigny Ltd.
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est renseigné invarié à 6 7/8 pour cent.

Au Stook Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a balssé de 1/8 à 82. L'Unifide a hausse de 1/4 99 1/4. Ia National Bank & été soutenue à 20, l'Agricole à 7 7/8 et la Delta Light à 9 7/8. La Daina á rétrograde de 1/4 à 12 1/4.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyption a perda 1 trang à 678. La Banque d'Athènes est restée inchangée à 108. Les Lots Tures ont gagné 1 fr. à 164.

Ici, notre marché privé d'un nouveau réconfort par suite des nouvelles insignifiantes du marché anglais, est retombé dans le marasme dont il avait essayé de sortir durant la séance d'hier. Après une ouverture assez bruyante pendant laquelle on s'est payé le luxe d'un semblant d'animation, le calme plat est revenu. L'approche de la cloture même n'a pas réussi à remuer nos boursiers. Inutile d'insister sur • le peu d'importance des transactions, la série de soubressats que nous venons de subir n'étant pas faite pour encourager les achetours.

Dans le groupe des Etablissements de Crédit, l'Agricole fléchit à 7 13/16 alors que la National Bank reste in variée à 20. La Banque d'o. rient se relève à 111-112. La Banque d'Es compte et de Reports se tasse à 2 9/16.

La Delta Light s'alourdit à 9 5,8. La Ramleh Railways tombe à 4. Les Jouissances Baux du Caire reculent encore à 154-155. Le Crédit Foncier Egyptien rétrograde á 675. L'Allot ment perd son avance d'hier à 1 15/16, de même que ses fondateurs à P.T. 47. La Compagnie Immobilière hausse de 5 fos. à 290. L'Agricole du Nil descend & 180. L'AngloAmerican Nile se consolide à 2 1/16.

Dans le compartiment des Hotels, les Nongovich perdent 1/4 8 15 3/4. Les Baebler sont on nouveau recul 8 4 3/4-13/16 ainsi que les Upper Egypt à 25/8. Les Excelsior Hotels sont également plus faibles À 1 13/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land est ramenée à 1 1/4, les Markets à 25/- et les fondateurs Estates à 2 1/2. L'Ordinary Khedivial Mail est en léger progrès à 20/9 et les fondateurs Express Nile Steamers sont en re prise à P.T. 25.
Nous recevons de notre correspondant de Londres, en date du 15 courant, les lignes suiYantes, concernant la tenue du groupe égyptien sur cette place:

"La tendance est en général faible et les transactions difficiles et restreintes. Sur les principales valeurs il suffit d'une demande ou d'une offre relativement, en temps normaux, peu importante pour influencer sensiblement les cours. On peut attribuer cet état de choses surtout à la crise financière aux Etats-Unis qui provoque la hausse des taux de toutes les Ban ques d'Europe et qui bouleverse toutes nos Bourses. Il est vrai que la situation en Egypte nécessite la continuation de ventes pour assainir les dossiers nantis, mais ces ventes auraient été sbsorbées avec facilité si la situstion générale financière avait été favorable.

"Les taux de reports des positions de micourant à fin courant ont été dans les environs de 8 % 11 %, et si la Banque d'Angleterre se voit obligé d'avancer son taux actuel qui est de 7 %, les reports à la liquidation prochaine deviendront très onéreux. Ce soir par suite de la continuation des demandes d'or pour l'Amérique on craint d'un moment à l'autre l'élévation du taux de la Banque à 8%.

"La National Bank a subi quelques fluctuations rapides, baissant à un moment à près de 19 1/2 pour avancer plus tard à 20 3/8 et eldturer i 20 1/8. L'Agricole avait baissé à un moment à 7 5/8, s'est relevée ensuite à 8 1/16 pour finir inchangée à 7 15/16. La Daïra de 12 1/4 s haussé à 12 3,4 pour finir très faible ce soir à 12 1/4. Sur les petites valeurs les affaires ont été pea importantes et la faiblesse prédomine."

Hier mstis s'est déroulé au Consulat d'Angleterre, Alexandrie, le prooes intenté par un groupe d'actionnaires de la Bourse and Banking au Conseil d'Administration. Le Tribunal a fait droit à la demande et n'a pas admis la validité des règlements faits sur les titres de la Société qui ont été négociés.
En ce qui concerne la nomination de M. A. Nahman comme liquidateur le tribunal d'est déclaré compétent.
Il a été immédiatement interjeté appel de ce jugement par l'avocat de la Société

div.head: THE BRITISH NAVY. PREPAREDNESS FOR WAR

div.p: Lord Charles Beresford, in a remarkable speech before the Salters Company on the preparedness of the navy, concluded by remarking that if any country prevoked war our practical preparedness would pulverise it. He emphasised that it was not the battleships but the human element which won. He pointed out Nelson's example. Nelson and his captains, he said, were like brothers.
(Reuter)

Lord Cromer, speaking at a banquet, illustrating the wisdom of Free Trade as a basis of imperial policy instanced a clause in the Sudan convention excluding trade preference. He also said that one reason why he was able to do good work in Egypt and get Europe to acquiesce to its continuance was the principles of Free Trade rigidly applied. Once abandon them and our occupation of Egypt would be regarded very differently. (Reuter)

Uproarious scenes were witnessed yesterday at the trial of Signor Nasi owing to the interruptions of Senators hostile to the accused. Signor Nasi's counsel and the president exchanged strong language. The counsel finally withdrew abandoning the defence. (Reuter)
The Nasi trial has been adjourned.
The prevailing opinion here is that the Senate has shown itself unsuitable as a court of justice.
(Reuter)

It is noticeable that the Minister of War is making numerous inspections of garrisons, while the King is participating in various military functions. It is believed that the army heartily supports the King. (Renter)

The strike situation is becoming worse. The attitude of the European strikers is threatening. Simla is isolated. A battalion of the Leinster Regiment and armed police are going to Assansol where the stranded passengers are collected. The Chamber of Commerce is intervening with a view to a settlement. (Reuter)
Three more leading newspapers have been suspended.
(Reuter)

A Papal "Motu Proprio" reiterates the declarations of the Syllabus of 18th July and the Encyclical of 16th September. It threatens those disregarding them with excommunication and other penalties. It urges episcopacy to exercise the utmost vigilance against books of modernist tendencies. (Reuter)
18 Italian navvies have been overwhelmed by a landslip near Cannes. Only two of them have been extricated alive.
(Reuter)
The Senate has opened the enquiry into the "Iena" catastrophe.
(Havas)

Owing to the widespread demands the premium on currency rose suddenly from 1½ to 3, resulting in disorder on the Exchange and causing renewed uneasiness. (Reuter)
Owing to the depression in trade crowds of aliens are leaving America and returning to Europe where they are able to live cheaper.
(Router)
It is announced in financial circles that a big bank in Paris is negotiating to send gold to America. Silence is kept on the subject of Official intervention in this affair. (Havas)
El Guebbas has been appointed Viceroy of the town, replacing Mohamed El Torres, who has retired. Ben Sliman will be appointed Premier.
(Havas)

div.head: R BROWN & CO.
div.p: A meeting of the creditor's of R. Brown and Co., was held at the Baltic House, 27, Leadenball Street, E.C., 1st July, 1907, of which the Following is the account : - Present - Reprementatives of: - Messrs. Barker and Allen, Ltd., Baynes, E. Co, Blackwood and Co., Bourne and Railton, Cadbury Bros., Ltd., Colman, J. and J., Ltd., Compton, J. and Sons, Hoare, Marr and Co., Holzenfel's Composition Co., Loskins and Sewell, Ltd., Kilner Bros and Co., Ltd., MeCorquodale and Co., Ltd., Moekin, Alfred, Ltd., Morgan, Crossley and Co., Ltd., Moseley, David and Co., Phillips and Son, Potosi Co., Prices' Patent Candles, Ltd., Rylands and Sons, Ltd, Stevenson. D. A. and Co., Jeffe Bros and Co.

Mr. C. Steward Cox (Director of Egyptian Investment and Agency, Ltd.) was voted into the chair. Mr. Cox said: I have no objection whatever to taking the chair if it is the unanimous wish of the creditors that I should, but I want to make it quite clear that we have no interest whatever in the matter of the liquidation, and never have had any interest, except so far as we could to safeguard the interest of the creditors, and if the meeting is not unanimous I would rather not do it. Mr. Cox was unanimously voted into the chair.

The Chairman said: I call upon Mr. Rowe, who acted as a member of the Committee of Inspection in Egypt, to give some account of what happened there. I think I will just again repeat that the Egyptian Investment and Agency have no interest in this matter whatever, that my Company took up the business of liquidating the Brown business in Egypt at the solicitation of Mr. Brown, and we agreed to begin to see whether we could so liquidate the business as in the interests of the parties concerned, and we here in London heard nothing about it except that Mr. Brown had made that request. The only thing that we did learn was from Mr. Hewett, one of our managers in Egypt-- who is present--that my company had the intention of liquidating the business, without making any stipulation about remuneration, for account of the concerned, in the hope of certain agency business resulting for us, partly as a consequence of assistance which had been given to creditors, and partly because my company believes that we can do credit to any business when it is put in our hands

Letter convening the meeting was read. Mr. Rowe said as I happened to be in Egypt at this particular time, I was put in the position of knowing perhaps more about it than most of you, and therefore I give you some explanaion of these affairs.

One or two letters I have received in reply to my letter convening the meeting, complained that the recipients had received no previous communication, and so, perhaps, it may be as well it I read to you the letter which was sent,I prusame, to all the creditors by Messrs. Brown and Co.

Since arriving home I have received another statement of affairs from Mr. Brown, dated May 20th, giving his liabilities as Ps. 26,722,051, and assets Ps. 2,220,720. In many cases, however, the figures are not correct, so this is of no use to us whatever.
The question being asked Mr. Rowe as to whether consignment stock could be earnaked by the owner, he replied that was a question to be settled.

Apart from the list of sundry creditors in Mr. Brown's liabilities are the two Banks, The Banque de Salonique Ps. 681,622, and Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio Ps. 416,415. These two Banks have got in all the Bills they could get hold of; they are all drawn on Messrs. R Brown and Co's own Bill forms, no matter whose goods they are against. The Banks are well covered for their amounts, and when they are wiped off they will hand the Bills (balance) over to the Liquidator, or Mr. Brown, or anybody duly appointed. With regard to stocks beld in consignment, I can only tell you that in many cases part or all have been sold and the money has gone into the Bank. I do not see how you are going to separate one stock from another, or decide which Bill is against which stock, as the goods of three or four creditors are lumped together in many cases and all on one Bill

In reply to a question from Messrs. Morgan, Crossley and Co.'s representative, Mr. Rowe said that we had no power to take possession of anything, but that one member on the committee, Messrs. Rylands representative, took possession of their stock, valued-I believe-at about £4,000, and to which action I protested at the time. The representative of Messrs Morgan. Crossely and Co., Ltd., said he would like to ask the chairman if Messrs. Rylands were prepared to return those goods.

Messrs. Rylands' representative said that he had no instructions from Messrs. Rylands, that we only knew of this matter an hour ago and could say nothing at the present time pending instructions, but he could say Messrs. Rylands would do the right thing.

Mr. Compton, of Messrs. J. Compton and Sons, said he would like to say that he was present with Mr. Rowe in Egypt. The first thing suggested was that Mr. Brown should be put through the Bankruptcy Court. They took both legal and commercial advice, with the result that everyone strongly advised their keeping out of the court.

It is of the greatest importance that something should be done at once; there is stock here and money coming in, and no one has any authority to act on behalf of the creditors, and that was the reason of calling this meeting. Messrs Brown's books have not been audited for three or four years.

Mr. Compton said he very much doubted if Mr. Kerr (the Accountant) would take the responsibility of a Deed of Assignment executed in his favour. Neither could we (the Committee) take the responsibility of that Deed; and release Mr. Brown of his indebtedness to us, and give him a free hand. We were legally advised on the other side that when Mr. Brown signed that Deed we had no further call on him.

Of course we had no control over sending these letters out, because we had no idea who Messrs. Brown's creditors were, we simply signed the letters placed before us. I think I shall give you a better idea of the state of affairs if I tell you what happened in our own case (Messrs. Hoskins and Sewell), I went out there on information received that things were not as they might be. When I got to Alexandria I had a letter put before me, in which Mr. Brown says, "that for various reasons, his managers leaving him, and one thing and another, he will have to suspend payment for the time being, and that he thinks it mpossible to carry on his business, and one of the reasons he gives is the impossibility of finding an honest man in the country, and so on." That is how I found the position when I got to Alexandria. The letter was dated 3rd May, 1907.

Then I went immediately into the question with Mr. Brown with regard to our accounts, and the stock we had in the country, and I asked Mr. Brown to let me know how that stock stood. After several days, I found that out of about £1,000 stock only about £100 remained unsold, and of this we had no advice or cash. Then I went on to our outstanding accounts in the country, which Mr. Brown collected as our agent, we paying him commision : and I found that a large number of these accounts had been collected and the money had not been remitted home, and the major portion of the remainder was covered by Bills drawn on R. Brown and Co.'s forms. There were Bills which we had drawn on him falling due at an early date, and I found there was no likelihood of their being met at due date. This was at the beginning of May.
Then Messrs. Rylands' representative arrived, and also Mr. Compton, and their cases I believe are identical with ours.

Mr. Brown promised us to make a statement of his affairs at the end of that week. His statement when presented showed liabilities, £30,000, and assets £28,000. But that statement was of very little use as it was found to be not at all correct, and made up to March 30th only.

We three--Mr. Southworth, Mr. Compton and myselt--then formed ourselves into a Committee of Inspection to protect the interest of the creditors, and went to Cairo to inspect the stock and check it. Needless to say we did not find it correct. Finding it was useless to rely upon Mr. Brown to give us any true idea of his affairs, we consulted Messrs Russell, Kerr and Wyatt, of Alexandria, Chartered Accountants, and asked them to examine Mr. Brown's books and prepare a statement of affairs showing the position up to 20th May, 1907. The report has not reached us yet. Mr. Kerr told me it would take at least four to six week, ie, may be finished by the end of next week.

We thought, however, instead of waiting for this report, that it was very necessary that the assets should be secured; we have absolutely no control over Mr. Brown at the present time, and we think it is very necessary that

somebody should be put into a position to pontrol the business over there, and, therefore on behalf of the committee I have called this meeting, and ask you to consent to the appointment of a liquidator.
Mr. Rowe was then asked if any other creditor had taken possession of their goods, and replied that to his knowledge they had not. Messrs. Rylands took possession about the 22nd. May.

The Chairman said that so far as he understood the matter, Messrs Rylands' goods were there without any charge on them, and he believed they had every justification for their action; but he expressed no opinion on the subject, except to assure them that Messrs. Rylands would undoubtedly do what was right.

The Solicitor of Egyptian Investment and Agency. Ltd. -- Mr. Leveaux--said that Mr. Kerr had already refused to obtain a Deed of Assigament, and it was highly necessary for the creditors to appoint somebody to represent them

It was then proposed that the meeting should be adjourned until the accounts from the auditors had come to hand. Mr. Compton said that while these matters were being discussed some provisional arrangements should be made, and suggested that the Meeting should empower the Egyptian Investment and Agency to protect ther interests.

After a good deal of discussion it was proposed by Mr. Payne, and seconded by Mr. Kilner, that a cable be sent to Egypt to the accountants, to know if the statement that has been mentioned had been sent off, or if not, when it will be sent off, and that another meeting of creditors be called on the information being received
Messrs. Rylands then agreed to submit the question of their retaining their stock as mentioned above to arbitration, granted that they approved of the arbitrator or counsel employed for the purpose.

It was then proposed by Mr. Compton, and seconded by Mr. Hoskins, that the Deed of Assignment as drawn, appointing the Egyptian Investment and Agency as Liquidators, be approved, subject to amendment by Messrs. Rylands' Solicitors, and Messrs. Morgan, Crossley and Co.'s Solicitors, and Mr. Leveaux the Egyptian Investment and Agency Co.'s Solicitor - on behalf of the creditors, as to whether Messrs. Rylands' action in taking possession of their stock could be legally justified or not. Messrs. Rylands undertaking to hand back the stock or its value to the estate in the latter event, the cost of arbitration being charged to the estate. This was carried unanimously, Messrs. Morgan, Crossley And Co. not voting.
The Chairman said his company would send out the telegram asking about the accounts and report.
The meeting was adjourned.
A reply to the cable has been since received from Egypt stating that the accounts will be ready in about fourteen days.
A meeting will be convened as soon as the acounts have arrived.
LAW REPORT.
MEETING OF CREDITORS, &c.
August 22nd.

Re Richard Brown & Co. storekeepers, Alexandria and Cairo. A meeting of creditors in this matter was held at Baltic House, LeadenWall Street, EC., on the 22nd ult, Mr. C. Stewart Cox, Director of the Egyptian Investnent and Agency, Ltd., being voted to the chair. --The statement of affairs showed liabilities £48,345, and assets estimated to realise £87,878, the latter including book debts £31,120, stock on hand £3,667, cash £1,548, ind investments £750. At a previous meeting the right of Messrs. Rylands and Sons, Ltd., to have received a portion of their stock was challenged, and agreed to be referred to Mr. E. W. Ansell, counsel to the Board of Trade, whose opinion was subeequently given in Messrs. Rylands favour.

There are numerous creditors who have sent goods on consignment, some of which have been sold, and the residue now forms part of the debtor's estate. There are instances where a portion of the stock so consigned has been disposed of to customers, and such sales have included the goods of numerous firms, in one transaction, while bills appear to have been drawn by Richard Brown and Co., and placed with their bankers or otherwise negotiated, so that it will be seen it will be impossible to earmark goods which have been so dealt with or where cash has been received in respect of goods sent on consignment and not remitted, and it was felt that if such manufacturers commenced proceedings for the return of any goods sent by them, litigation must ensue, with the result that the state would have to be administered according to the Mixed Law prevailing in Egypt, which mean protracted and expensive proceedings, and be disadvanageous to the creditors.

It was suggested that the wisest course in this now would be for all to share and share alike, and Messrs. Rylands and Sons, Ltd., have consented, conditional on this course being adopted, to return the bills received by them amounting to about £2,000 (retaining the goods they already hold). It was therefore resolved that the creditors be recommended to assent to the estate being assigned for the benefit of creditors, and that the Egyptian Investment and Agency, Ltd., be appointed trustees, with a committee of inspection ponsisting of four of the principal creditors, viz., Messrs. Hoskins and Sewell, Ltd., Messrs. Raylands and Sons, Ltd., Messrs. J. Compton and Sons, and Messrs John Shaw and Sons, Wolverhampton, Ltd., to act with the Egyptian Investment and Agency, Ltd., and to assist in the winding-up (the deed to be approved on behalf of the creditors), the Egyptian Investment and Agency, Ltd., having agreed to undertake the work, and without charge, if it is the unanimous wish of the creditors they should do so.

The following circular was issued by Mr. G. G. Poppleton (Messrs. Poppleton and Appleby), 4, Charterhouse Square, E C., on the 27th ult. :– "I beg to inform you that the Committee of Inspection that was appointed in this matter met here yesterday, when the following resolution was passed : That Mr. G. G. Poppleton, C.A., be requested to obtain for the Egyptian Investment and Agency, Ltd, the assents of the creditors, and generally to assist in carrying out the proposed deed of assignment.'– (Signed), H. W. Compton (J. Compton and Sons), L. Rowe (Hoskins and Sewell, Ltd.) E. C. Dunford (Rylands and Sons, Ltd.) C. B. Shaw (John Shaw and Sons, Wolverhampton, Ltd.). In accordance therewith I have pleasure in enclosing herewith the Committee's report of the meeting together with a form of assent in order that some unanimous course may be decided upon."
From "The Mercantile Guardian"

div.head: THE COTTON MAKKET.
KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAX'S WEEKLY REPORT
div.p: The demand for Spot Egyptians has been small this week.
In quotations of Good, Fair and Fully Good, Fair Brown are raised to 1/16 plb. whilst Good is reduced to 1/16 plb. Uppers are unchanged.
A fair business has been done in Futures, and the following are the latest quotations -
Dec. 9.48 Mar. 9.45 June 9.46 Sep: 9.47
Jan. 9.46 Apr. 9.45 July 9.47 Oct. 9.41

American Futures. The Market this week has been in a very unsettled state, at one time the feeling was strong with a substantial advance in prices, there being a feeling that financial matters in America were less acute, but later there was less buoyancy and the Market reacted somewhat.
Bad weather was reported from the Cotton States, with Frost in some sections. It is however too late for frost to do much injury, still it may stop further growth.

There is, we think, a more confident feeling and many consider that Cotton at about 5 ½ plb. is by no means dear if the monetary position in the United States were in a more settled state. There is however almost a total absence of outside speculation, the fluctuations of prices in the market being merely due to the Room operators taking a view one side or the other for the time being.
We fear it may be some time before the atmosphere is clear enough for people to take a calm view of the position after so serious a financial crisis.
The latest values are delivery :
November 5.63½ Feb/Mar. 5.58 June/July 5.59½
Nov./Dec. 5.57. Mar./Apr. 5.58½ July/Aug. 5.58 ½
Dec/Jan. 5.57 April/May 5.59
